programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest news from the BBC.

programme.title: The Media Show
programme.desc: Jeremy Vine joins The Media Show to discuss his recent court victories over Joey Barton, the former footballer who earlier this month received a suspended prison sentence for offensive social media posts. The case has raised questions about where criticism ends and criminal conduct begins. The mass shooting at Bondi Beach during a Hanukkah event created major challenges for journalists trying to confirm fast-moving details. Newsrooms had to decide how to describe the attack, when to name suspects, and how to treat unverified online posts. Jacqueline Maley, senior writer at the Sydney Morning Herald, explains the decisions behind early reporting and the influence of social media. In Florida, Donald Trump has filed a defamation case against the BBC over an edited sequence in the Panorama documentary, which triggered the resignation of the corporation's Director General and its CEO of News. Stuart M Benjamin, professor of law at Duke University, sets out the legal issues.

programme.title: I Was There
programme.desc: A deadly nerve agent is released in Salisbury. Former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia are both poisoned. An innocent member of the community, Dawn Sturgess, died. After an inquiry looked into the events of 2018 and what happened to Dawn Sturgess. We hear from those who were on the ground and at the centre of the story.

programme.title: Access All Areas
programme.desc: For the first time in its 100 years, the Grand Ole Opry, has left Nashville. For one night only, country's biggest stars came together at the Royal Albert Hall to make music history. When Country Comes to Town, goes behind the scenes at rehearsals and speaks to country music royalty such as Luke Combs, Darius Rucker and Carly Pearce to find out what it takes to pull off a historic gig like this. UK artists Mumford & Sons and Breabach also played, joining the exclusive list of stars who have previously performed at the Opry, such as Johnny Cash and Dolly Parton.

programme.title: AI Decoded
programme.desc: AI Decoded features Google DeepMind's Gemini Robotics lab, where researchers use artificial intelligence to enable robots to perceive, plan, think, use tools and act to better solve complex, multi-step tasks. programme.title: Global Women
programme.desc: Greenlandic parents across Denmark are fighting to be reunited with their children, who were taken into care after authorities used 'parenting competency tests' as part of assessments to judge their ability to raise them. After banning the tests for use on Greenlandic people, the Danish government has now pledged to review around 300 child removals, but not everyone's cases are being looked at.

programme.title: Mortdecai
programme.desc: Armed with only his good looks and special charm, an art dealer (Johnny Depp) travels the world to find a stolen painting that is rumored to contain the code to a bank account filled with Nazi gold.

programme.title: Killers
programme.desc: A woman's perfect suburban life explodes in a hail of bullets when she learns that her husband is an international superspy.

programme.title: Red
programme.desc: Retired CIA agents (Bruce Willis, Morgan Freeman, John Malkovich) reassemble for survival after the agency sends assassins to silence them and the secrets they carry.

programme.desc: Former CIA black-ops agent Frank Moses (Bruce Willis) and his team battle assassins, terrorists and power-hungry government officials as they try to retrieve a lethal device that could change the balance of world power.

programme.title: Hercules in New York
programme.desc: Banished from Mount Olympus, Hercules is sent to Earth where he finds true love and becomes a bodybuilder.

programme.title: Mazes and Monsters
programme.desc: Robbie and his three college classmates decide to move their board game into the local legendary cavern.
